contentencoded:
Good-bye, midnight Snickers bar. Adios, Pringles cylinder. Sayonara, bourbon nightcap.

They may never go away completely, but the hotel minibar can certainly be considered a rare and endangered species.

Why are minibars vanishing?

"In Las Vegas, a little bottle of vodka can cost you more than $14. And in Washington D.C., if you want a bag of peanuts, be prepared to pay over $7," says Kevin Carter with the travel planning website TripAdvisor.

A recent TripAdvisor survey found just 7 percent of U.S. travelers even remotely care about a minibar in the room. Not surprisingly, PKF Hospitality found that between 2007–2012 minibar revenue fell by nearly 30 percent.

Disappearing minibars is just one of several changes in modern-day U.S. hotel rooms. Woodworth says what hotels lose in certain antiquated amenities, companies hope to make up in room rates.

"If I can get you to pay an extra dollar for your room tonight, about 90 cents of that is pure profit," says Woodworth. "The energies and management focus has been really optimizing room revenues."

TripAdvisor found travelers want a lot of stuff that starts with the word "free": Free wifi. Free breakfast. Free parking.

Oh, and we want outlets – lots and lots of electrical outlets.     

5 more "amenities" disappearing from your hotel room

PKF Hospitality President Mark Woodworth says hotels are recalculating what makes them money. Here are five services on the chopping block: 

1. Dry cleaning.

There will still be ironing boards, but you'll have to push them yourself.

[[{"fid":"263406","view_mode":"primary_image","fields":{"format":"primary_image","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":false,"field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"Dry cleaner","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"Hulton Archive/Getty Images","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"title":"Dry cleaner","class":"styles file-styles embed_display media-element file-primary-image","id":"styles-0-0"}}]]

2. Telephone services. 

Perhaps wake up calls will be rerouted to cell phones.

[[{"fid":"263411","view_mode":"primary_image","fields":{"format":"primary_image","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":false,"field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"Film starlet Olga Nielsen on the phone in a London hotel. ","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty Images","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"title":"Film starlet Olga Nielsen on the phone in a London hotel. ","class":"styles file-styles embed_display media-element file-primary-image","id":"styles-0-0"}}]]

3. Renting movies on hotel TVs. 

Enough guests prefer their own screens. 

[[{"fid":"263416","view_mode":"primary_image","fields":{"format":"primary_image","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":"","field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"A couple watching TV in a brand new hotel room, circa 1955","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"Jimmy Sime/Hulton Archive/Getty Images","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"title":"A couple watching TV in a brand new hotel room, circa 1955","class":"styles file-styles embed_display media-element file-primary-image","id":"styles-0-0"}}]]

4. Room size.

The smaller the room, the bigger the hotel's profit. And the closer you are to your cell phone, which is what you care about anyway. 

[[{"fid":"263421","view_mode":"primary_image","fields":{"format":"primary_image","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":"","field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"A spacious hotel room. Goodbye, space.","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"Hulton Archive/Getty Images","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"title":"A spacious hotel room. Goodbye, space.","class":"styles file-styles embed_display media-element file-primary-image","id":"styles-0-0"}}]]

5. Coffee makers.

For now, the coffee makers are still there -- but you have to pay for anything you brew. 

[[{"fid":"263426","view_mode":"primary_image","fields":{"format":"primary_image","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":false,"field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"The Beatles taking a coffee break","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"Hulton Archive/Getty Images","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"title":"The Beatles taking a coffee break","class":"styles file-styles embed_display media-element file-primary-image","id":"styles-0-0"}}]]
teaser: Today's hotel room is tomorrow's museum exhibit.
itags: Marketplace Morning Report for Friday May 2, 2014
title: Time to mourn the minibar
